report_title: Fish & Seafood Markets in the US
executive_summary: Figures have been adjusted for inflation and are presented in 2024 currency. Fish and seafood markets comprise establishments that retail primarily fresh, frozen and cured fish and seafood items, including the online sales of fish products or fish. Seafood counters that operate within a supermarket aren't included. Expanding per capita seafood consumption and rising per capita disposable income have also benefited companies in the fish and seafood market. Also, the growing incidence of heart disease and obesity in the United States has encouraged consumers to incorporate finfish and fish oil into their diets. Coupled with a renewed interest in locally sourced food, health and nutrition trends emphasizing the importance of eating seafood have driven growth. However, boosting external competition with larger supercenter retailers has made it difficult for fish and seafood markets to compete on pricing. Industry-wide revenue has been growing at an average annualized 2.7% over the past five years and is expected to total $4.3 billion in 2024, when revenue will rise by an estimated 0.8%. Interest in the health benefits of seafood consumption has driven demand for fish and seafood products; however, pricing and consumer trends have also impacted fish and seafood market revenue and profit. Although per capita seafood consumption has dipped, the seafood prices have swelled. As the economy recovers, strengthening disposable income levels will keep demand steady despite higher prices.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: REVENUE GROWS AS PRICES EDGE UPWARD
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: COVID-19 made buying feed much more expensive, driving up fish prices, which led fish and seafood markets to pass on boosted costs to downstream industries and consumers. Although the pandemic drove up seafood prices and led many consumers to avoid shopping for groceries in person, some consumers made fish and seafood purchases online, which helped support revenue. As disposable income strengthens alongside per capita seafood consumption and the price of seafood, domestic consumers shift away from lower-priced canned or frozen seafood in favor of more expensive and higher-margin steaks and filets of fish and seafood.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: AN EXPANDING HEALTH-CONSCIOUS CONSUMER BASE BOOSTS DEMAND
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: The swelling incidence of certain ailments, like obesity and heart disease, has caused many consumers to make healthier choices when it comes to their diet. Various organizations, including the American Heart Association, have recommended that adults boost their intake of foods that are relatively high in omega-3 fatty acids to prevent and manage heart disease, expanding the popularity of seafood with high omega-3 content, including salmon, oysters, trout and tuna. Serious outbreaks of foodborne illnesses like E. coli, salmonella and listeria have helped encourage consumers to purchase local produce, including meat and seafood, steering them toward more locally sourced, fresher products.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: EXTERNAL COMPETITION AND ENVIRONMENTAL CONCERNS POSE A THREAT
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Consumers traditionally purchase finfish and shellfish fish markets. However, more consumers have turned to grocery stores, warehouse clubs and supercenters because of their value and convenience.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: A boost in per capita disposable income and consumer spending will bring consumers back from cheaper substitutes to seafood. Seafood's solid reputation brings in business, but fish markets struggle with the stigma that higher price tags bring on their products. Revenue expansion is greatest when disposable income is high, which will continue to challenge fish and seafood markets.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: DESPITE HEALTH BENEFITS, HEALTH AND ENVIRONMENTAL CONCERNS LIMIT DEMAND
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Expanding health-consciousness and the perceived benefits of consuming finfish and shellfish will help maintain demand for seafood. The heightened publicity regarding the mercury content of certain fish and seafood items has discouraged some consumers from purchasing fish and seafood. High levels of mercury in humans are linked to negative health conditions including neurological and chromosomal problems, in addition to birth defects. The warming of the oceans has also driven demand for more environmentally conscious sustainable and responsibly caught seafood that considers overfishing laws, low carbon transportation and safe catching practices.

industry_definition: Fish and seafood markets primarily retail fresh, frozen and cured fish and seafood items, including tuna, salmon, lobster and shrimp. Products are sold at various brick-and-mortar locations including independent markets, delicatessens, fishmongers and butcher shops. Fish and seafood markets and counters operating within a supermarket are excluded from this industry, but online sales of fish products are included, as are other direct selling establishments.

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level low - steady

key_trends: Interest in the health benefits of seafood consumption has driven demand for fish and seafood products. However, pricing and consumer trends have also impacted fish and seafood market revenue and profit.

Competitive pressures from big-box retailers have strengthened as more Americans seek the convenience of shopping in a single location. Larger retailers have high purchasing power, allowing them to price various premium goods competitively.
Fish and seafood markets benefit from more Americans becoming expansively health-conscious. Many consumers have turned to seafood as a healthy alternative to other sources of protein, like red meat.

Regulations are covered by federal laws regarding employment, product handling, nutrition labeling and other matters pertaining to fish and seafood markets. Individual states have also enacted their own laws to ensure consumers aren't disadvantaged with unfair pricing of seafood products.

Food retailers adhere to the FDA's Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act regarding the receipt, storage and selling of fish and seafood. Under the same act, the FDA enforces proper labeling and use of specific terms like "catfish."

Fresh fish represent the most significant product group. Sales of fresh finfish, in particular, are expected to make up most sales, with salmon being the top selling and others including tilapia, pollock, cod, tuna and catfish.
Many fish markets will sell spices and ingredients for side dishes that are commonly paired with fish, as well as beverages, utensils and novelty items.

Fish and seafood markets are located near large population centers along the coasts, with easy access to fresh seafood. The regions with the highest concentration of fish and seafood markets are the Mid-Atlantic, Southeast and West.
Fish and seafood markets compete based on the quality of products, range of services and products offered, location and price. Freshness and variety are two bases of competition.

Fish and seafood markets endure intense competition from supermarkets and grocery stores. The size of these companies allows them to purchase goods from retailers in bulk at much lower prices, allowing them to charge lower prices for seafood than fish and seafood markets.
Most fish and seafood markets are small, independent and privately-owned enterprises with only one storefront.
Purchases consistently account for most of an average fish and seafood market's revenue. Wage costs are also high since operating a fish and seafood market is a very labor-intensive pursuit.

market_segmentation.segment_description: Many fish and seafood markets are locally owned and largely serve the needs of individual customers and households. Among consumers, those that earn higher incomes account for a greater share of fish and seafood consumption with consumers that are in the highest income bracket contributing a substantial share of revenue. Seafood consumption among higher-income individuals is particularly high because seafood is more expensive than other sources of protein including red meat and poultry.

Many fish and seafood markets are locally owned and largely serve the needs of individual customers and households. Among consumers, those that earn higher incomes account for a greater share of fish and seafood consumption with consumers that are in the highest income bracket contributing a substantial share of revenue. Seafood consumption among higher-income individuals is particularly high because seafood is more expensive than other sources of protein including red meat and poultry.

Other seafood retailers and wholesalers may purchase large quantities of fish from fish and seafood markets for resale. Despite having already passed through wholesale seafood distribution channels, these products may, nevertheless, be purchased once again by retailers and wholesalers that wish to buy fish or seafood to further transform these products or buy them after the industry's markets have made modifications to them.

Single-location restaurants, chain restaurants, hotels, food services and other contract feeding entities purchase fish and seafood from fish and seafood markets. Single-location restaurants are more likely to source fish and seafood from a local market in an attempt to offer customers fresh, high-quality products. Meanwhile, chains are more likely to source fish and seafood from wholesale distributors that can deliver large quantities at a time. This segment's share of industry revenue has expanded as recovering disposable income levels have allowed consumers to dine out more often, and renewed interest in locally sourced ingredients has led more single-location restaurants to source seafood products from local markets.

Other seafood retailers and wholesalers may purchase large quantities of fish from fish and seafood markets for resale. Despite having already passed through wholesale seafood distribution channels, these products may, nevertheless, be purchased once again by retailers and wholesalers that wish to buy fish or seafood to further transform these products or buy them after the industry's markets have made modifications to them.
No description provided for this segment.

products_and_services.product_description: Sales of fresh finfish, in particular, comprise a substantial portion of industry sales in the current year, with salmon being the top selling species, known for its rich flavor and high nutritional value. Other popular finfish commonly sold at fish markets include tilapia, pollock, cod, tuna and catfish.

While finfish remain the most popular products at fish markets, fresh shellfish also generate a sizable share of revenue. The most popular shellfish species is shrimp, which can be prepared in countless ways and typically contains low levels of mercury, and other popular shellfish include clams, oysters, crab and lobster.

Some markets will sell prepared fish that are already pre-seasoned, cooked and ready to be served. Preparing seafood can be relatively difficult for those that are not well-experienced in cooking food. That's why some consumers prefer these ready-to-eat options as they remove much of the hassle that comes with eating at home.

Fish markets will typically sell a variety of other goods in addition to seafood products, including spices and ingredients for side dishes that are commonly paired with fish. Also, some markets will offer beverages, utensils and novelty items.

tier_1_buyers: Single Location Full-Service Restaurants in the US
Food Service Contractors in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Fish & Seafood Aquaculture in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Fresh Fish Represent the Largest Product Group
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Sales of fresh finfish, in particular, comprise a substantial portion of industry sales in the current year, with salmon being the top selling species, known for its rich flavor and high nutritional value. Other popular finfish commonly sold at fish markets include tilapia, pollock, cod, tuna and catfish.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Frozen Fish is Another Good Option
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Fish and seafood markets serve as trustworthy sources of fresh fish, which is relatively difficult to come across when compared with other products like chicken or beef. That's why these markets tend to avoid selling a large portion of frozen products. Consumers typically have no issue finding frozen fish at any local supermarket, which makes pricing competition very high. This segment is likely to have risen slightly compared with others as consumers sought out goods that could be stored for long periods amid the COVID-19 pandemic.

business_locations.location_description: The Mid-Atlantic region has the highest percentage of both establishments (around 30%) and population (around 15%) compared to other regions. This indicates that a dense and diverse population in the Mid-Atlantic region attracts a higher concentration of fish and seafood markets, likely due to the presence of major population hubs like New York City and Philadelphia in this region. A variety of cultural preferences in Mid-Atlantic cities, New York City in particular, drives demand for fish and seafood products. New York City is home to some of the most renowned fish and seafood restaurants, contributing to the city's demand for quality fish and seafood markets.

The Southeast is known for its abundance of fish and seafood that are indigenous to the waters in this region. Locating near upstream suppliers minimizes transportation costs and ensures that fish and seafood products remain fresh. Fish and seafood markets also capitalize on Southern cuisine's love of fish and seafood.

The West Coast is located nearby the Pacific Ocean, which provides efficient access to fresh fish and seafood, encouraging markets to source their inventory directly from local fisheries and fisherman. The expansively diverse population in the region, many of who are health-conscious, boosts demand for fish and seafood markets.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The FDA oversees food manufacturing, storage, labeling and nutritional requirements to ensure product quality and safety.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Fish and Fisheries Products Hazards and Controls Guidance
regulations_points.regulation_description: FDA guidance on hazards, prevention and control methods to safeguard public health for fish and fish products.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Safety and Fraud Enforcement for Seafood Act
regulations_points.regulation_description: Enforces traceability and verification of seafood origin to protect consumers and support sustainable fishing practices.
Requires tolerance levels and sampling for methylmercury in seafood, especially for vulnerable groups.
Social distancing guidelines limited number of patrons and required layout changes during the pandemic.

basis_points.basis_description: Fish and seafood markets compete based on the quality of products.
Fish and seafood markets compete based on the range of services and products offered.
Fish and seafood markets compete based on location.
Fish and seafood markets compete based on price.
Freshness is a basis of competition. Customers are willing to pay a premium for fresh products.
Variety is a basis of competition. Customers value a wide range of seafood options.

concentration_points.concentration_description: Meat markets differentiate themselves from external competition (supermarkets and grocery stores) by sourcing their fish and seafood locally and offering small-scale customer service.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Nature of products necessitates low concentration
concentration_points.concentration_description: Fish and seafood have a relatively short shelf life, which means that many fish and seafood markets are located near ports and the opportunity to expand into noncoastal areas is slim.

The presence of vertically integrated seafood companies that catch, process and retail seafood products has made fish and seafood markets somewhat niche components within the seafood supply chain that has limited opportunity for expansion.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Depreciation accounts for a marginal amount of revenue
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Depreciation accounts for a marginal amount of an average market's revenue.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases are the major cost component
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Purchases consistently account for most of an average fish and seafood market's revenue.
Operating a fish and seafood market is a very labor-intensive pursuit.
Profit has edged upward as consumers are willing to pay premium prices for sustainably sourced fish and seafood.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The Fish and Seafood Markets industry is labor-intensive, requiring skilled workers to cut and prepare fish and seafood.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low rate of new patents and patent concentration
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The industry is experiencing a low level of both the rate of new patents and the concentration of patents in the industry.
Major market segments for industry operators are relatively diversified.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Sales surged as consumers sought local, high-quality fish and seafood to cook at home during pandemic restaurant closures.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Fish and seafood recalls impact sales
volatility_points.volatility_description: Outbreaks of contamination and product recalls can steer consumers away from fish and seafood markets.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Fresh fish is the largest product segment
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Sales of fresh finfish like salmon, tilapia and cod comprise a substantial portion of industry sales.
Frozen fish products face high pricing competition from supermarkets but saw a rise during the pandemic.
Some markets sell pre-seasoned, cooked and ready-to-eat fish products for consumer convenience.
Fish markets often sell complementary items like spices, side dishes, beverages and novelty items.

FAQs.question: Are your sales dependent on a seasonal or cyclical cycle?
FAQs.answer: Some species of fish are only available for harvest during specific seasons. Fish markets that can retail out-of-season species will earn a premium.

FAQs.question: Does your company specialize in one corner of the market or retail a diversified product range?
FAQs.answer: Diversified fish markets can better protect themselves from price volatility. Specialized producers can earn wider margins on premium fish like tuna and salmon but expose themselves to a greater risk of price volatility.

FAQs.question: How do global fish stock numbers impact your business?
FAQs.answer: Fish and seafood markets receive indirect assistance from associations that work with fish and seafood markets' upstream suppliers. Fish and seafood markets benefit from marketing initiatives undertaken by these associations.

FAQs.question: Seafood prices are a function of global fish stocks, and overfishing can cause seafood prices to expand. Aquaculture has the potential to stabilize prices and ensure supply.
FAQs.answer: Seafood prices are a function of global fish stocks, and overfishing can cause seafood prices to expand. Aquaculture has the potential to stabilize prices and ensure supply.

FAQs.question: Does your company have contracts with upstream suppliers and downstream retail outlets?
FAQs.answer: Fish markets with exclusive supply contracts can hedge against future price volatility by locking in predetermined rates. A number of fish markets have contracts with downstream restaurants and food service establishments, ensuring an outlet for their fish products.

FAQs.question: Does your company have any significant e-commerce presence? How may it be possible to expand sales by reaching consumers online?
FAQs.answer: Fish and seafood markets risk losing market share if they aren't able to build an online presence.

FAQs.question: Has your company been able to minimize wage costs via the adoption of the latest technologies?
FAQs.answer: Fish markets are highly labor intensive and require specialized employees. Adopting the latest technologies like electronic inventory management or point-of-sale systems can trim the number of necessary non-skilled employees.

FAQs.question: How does your company ensure that health and safety requirements are upheld?
FAQs.answer: As a perishable food, seafood must be stored and prepared properly, in accordance with the law. Not only are noncompliant fish markets subject to legal recourse, but their public reputation will suffer, potentially losing customers to competitors.

FAQs.question: Is your company adequately prepared to adjust to changing regulatory standards?
FAQs.answer: Due to the need to protect certain species from overfishing, the government has stepped in to rehabilitate fish stocks.

FAQs.question: How does your company's profit compare with those of your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Fish markets selling high-margin fish like salmon steaks and swordfish will earn a premium, expanding profit.

FAQs.question: How does your company's inventory turnover compare to that of your competitors?
FAQs.answer: Fish markets selling at the lowest price will have the quickest inventory turnover.

FAQs.question: What is the training process for new hires like? How much prior experience is necessary for workers at your market?
FAQs.answer: Fish and seafood markets with knowledgeable staff have a competitive advantage over competitors because consumers will feel as though they receive a premium service when visiting a fish market rather than a normal supermarket or grocery store. It's important that fish and seafood markets maintain an experienced and knowledgeable staff in order to make consumers feel confident that they are purchasing a safe, high-quality product.

FAQs.question: Fresh fish and seafood products must be sold quickly as they have a limited shelf life and can't be stored for long. At the same time, it's important that retailers maintain adequate stock levels to satisfy consumer demand.
FAQs.answer: Fresh fish and seafood products must be sold quickly as they have a limited shelf life and can't be stored for long. At the same time, it's important that retailers maintain adequate stock levels to satisfy consumer demand.

FAQs.question: Why do many fish and seafood markets find it useful to locate near key markets?
FAQs.answer: Fish and seafood markets often locate near key markets to ensure the freshest supply for their customers, capitalizing on high foot traffic and proximity to customers. Being closer to the market also reduces transportation costs and delivery time.

FAQs.question: How do you monitor changes in the price of seafood?
FAQs.answer: As the price of seafood expands, fish and seafood markets often boost product prices. Higher prices for fish and seafood products often push up revenue as consumers pay a larger price for the final product.

FAQs.question: What proportion of demand comes from food service establishments and drinking places?
FAQs.answer: As consumers dine out more frequently at full-service restaurants, demand for fish and seafood goods edges upward, supporting revenue expansion.

FAQs.question: Are certain products of yours purchased more than others? What trends have you noticed in the popularity of certain products over others?
FAQs.answer: As consumers boost overall consumption of fish and shellfish, demand for goods offered by fish and seafood markets surges.
